证据片段: Zircaloy-4 tubes were oxidized at temperatures ranging from 1173 to 1573 K

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: compressed at 373 K

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: simulated Zircaloy-clad fuel rods were burst and oxidized in steam at temperatures within the range 1200 to 1500 K

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: bottom-flooded at the oxidation temperature or 773 K with water

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: additional embrittlement due to hydrogen absorption is found to be significant in burst cladding

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: estimated thermal-shock-failure boundary under a restrained condition is located above the 15% oxidation line

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: maximum clad temperature shall not exceed 1473 K

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: total oxygen consumption...shall not exceed 15% of the total clad thickness

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: Zircaloy cladding material has the chemical composition 1.46 Sn-0.22 Fe-0.10 Cr-0.008 C-0.140 O-0.002 H-0.0018 N

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: heated by an infrared furnace in steam with flow rate of 267 g/m² s

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: sectioned into nine segments, each of which was 15-mm long

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: compressed at 373 K

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk1
证据片段: 500-mm-long Zircaloy-clad fuel rod was exposed to steam at isothermal temperatures within the range 1173 to 1573 K

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk2
证据片段: fracture position is 45 mm below the location of the rupture opening

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk3
证据片段: When a Zircaloy cladding tube is oxidized to 15% (calculated by the BakerJust coefficient) in the total clad thickness at 1473 K, its deflection at 373 K is estimated to be 1.0 mm by the ring-compression test, as shown in Fig. 3.

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk3
证据片段: In Fig. 6, the 1.0-mm equivalent deflection line due to hydrogen uptake limits the permissible oxidation condition to a considerably lower temperature and to shorter exposure times, compared with oxygen uptake alone.

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk3
证据片段: The fracture position of burst cladding failed on quenching does not correspond with the place where the highest hydrogen content or the minimum thickness of transformed β-phase layer can be detected, as shown in Fig. 9.

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk3
证据片段: The ballooned region is axially the weakest location in strength.

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk4
证据片段: Out-of-pile experiments have been performed to investigate the escalation in temperature of Zircaloy-clad fuel rods during heatup in steam due to the exothermal Zircaloy steam reaction

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk4
证据片段: The initial heating rates were varied from 0.3 to 2.5 K/s

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk4
证据片段: The maximum measured surface temperature was about 2200°C

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk4
证据片段: Damage to the fuel rods increased with increasing heatup rate

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk4
证据片段: For slow heatup rates nearly no interaction between the oxidized cladding and UO2 was observed

文献ID: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_051_chunk4
证据片段: for fast heatup rates the entire annular pellet was dissolved by molten Zircaloy
